title: Measuring What Matters: Impact Framework

problem_statement.headline: Traditional youth justice metrics fail young people
key_points: Recidivism rates (reoffending within X years) remain the dominant measure of 'success'
This narrow focus misses the holistic reality of transformation
Programs are defunded when they don't reduce recidivism fast enough—even if they're improving lives
Young people become statistics, not people on journeys
Indigenous communities have long known that healing can't be reduced to a single number
problem_statement.system_critique: When we measure only what's convenient rather than what matters, we optimise for the wrong outcomes. A young person who stays out of detention but remains isolated, unemployed, and disconnected from culture isn't thriving. A program that builds genuine connection and cultural identity but takes time to show 'official' results may be doing the deepest work.

solution_overview.headline: JusticeHub measures what actually matters
solution_overview.approach: ALMA (Adaptive Learning & Measurement Architecture) - a holistic impact framework that uses SIGNALS (direction indicators) not SCORES (rankings)
core_philosophy: Transformation is a journey, not a destination to be ranked
Community authority is weighted highest - those closest to the work define success
Impact emerges at different time horizons - some changes take years to manifest
Multiple beneficiaries matter - young person, family, community, system

signals_not_scores.title: Signals, Not Scores
signals_not_scores.explanation: Instead of ranking programs 1-10 or comparing them competitively, ALMA uses directional signals:

levels.name: High Impact
levels.meaning: This story/program is creating meaningful change

levels.name: Emerging Impact
levels.meaning: This story/program is beginning its journey

signals_not_scores.why_it_matters: Scores create competition. Signals create learning. Every program at every stage is valued.

holistic_outcomes.title: 12 Outcome Types
holistic_outcomes.explanation: Success looks different for every young person. ALMA tracks outcomes across multiple dimensions:
holistic_outcomes.why_it_matters: A young person might not 'reduce recidivism' for years—but they might reconnect with family, engage with school, and begin cultural healing tomorrow. All of this matters.

evidence_with_cultural_authority.title: Evidence That Respects Community Knowledge
evidence_with_cultural_authority.explanation: ALMA recognises multiple forms of evidence, not just academic research:

evidence_levels.name: Untested
evidence_levels.meaning: Theory/pilot stage - still valuable for learning

evidence_with_cultural_authority.why_it_matters: An Indigenous-led program with community authority and cultural grounding may have more real-world validity than a program 'proven' in a completely different context. Both forms of evidence deserve recognition.

time_horizons.title: Time Horizons
time_horizons.explanation: Different outcomes manifest at different speeds:
time_horizons.why_it_matters: Funding cycles often demand results within 12 months. Real transformation often takes 3+ years. ALMA makes visible the early indicators that predict long-term success.

multiple_beneficiaries.title: Multiple Beneficiaries

beneficiaries.name: Community
beneficiaries.example: Increased safety, role models for others

beneficiaries.name: System/Government
beneficiaries.example: Cost savings, better outcomes at scale

multiple_beneficiaries.why_it_matters: Traditional metrics only count what happens to the young person. But when a young person transforms, their family heals, their community strengthens, and the system becomes more effective. All of this is impact.

data_sovereignty.headline: Communities Control Their Data
key_principles: Consent ledger: Every piece of data has clear consent level and permitted uses
Community-controlled data stays within community control
Cultural authority is documented and respected
Indigenous communities retain sovereignty over their stories and outcomes
Revenue sharing for commercial use of community data
data_sovereignty.why_it_matters: Impact data about Indigenous young people has historically been extracted, analysed, and published without community consent or benefit. ALMA ensures data sovereignty is built into the architecture.

young_people_families.what_you_see: Your journey shown through signals, not scores. Progress celebrated at every stage.
young_people_families.key_benefit: You're more than a statistic. Your healing, your growth, your path—all of it counts.

service_providers.what_you_see: Dashboard showing holistic outcomes across all 12 types, with time horizons and beneficiary impact.
service_providers.key_benefit: Tell the full story of your impact, not just the parts that fit traditional metrics.

funders.what_you_see: Portfolio analysis showing evidence strength, community authority, and implementation capability.
funders.key_benefit: Invest with confidence in programs that show real-world effectiveness, not just academic proof.

policymakers.what_you_see: System-level insights showing which approaches work, where, and for whom.
policymakers.key_benefit: Evidence-informed policy that respects community authority and local context.

article_structure.suggested_title: Measuring What Matters: Why JusticeHub Tracks More Than Recidivism

structure.approach: Open with story of a program defunded despite life-changing impact - because it didn't reduce recidivism 'fast enough'
Explain why recidivism is a flawed measure - too narrow, too slow, ignores context
Introduce the 12 outcome types and multiple beneficiaries
Explain the ALMA approach - growth framing, not competitive ranking
Show how different changes happen at different speeds
Explain multiple evidence types including Indigenous-led and community authority
Communities control their stories and their data
Preview the impact dashboard for different audiences
Invite programs to register, funders to partner, communities to share

tone_guidance.voice: Confident but humble. Challenging the status quo without being preachy.
tone_guidance.approach: Position JusticeHub as part of a movement, not as having all the answers.
do: Use concrete examples of what different outcome types look like
Acknowledge the complexity of measuring human transformation
Credit the community knowledge this framework builds on
Show, don't tell - let the framework speak for itself
avoid: Don't disparage traditional research or evidence-based approaches
Don't claim ALMA is perfect or complete - it's evolving
Don't oversimplify - transformation is genuinely complex
Don't make promises about outcomes we can't deliver

review_notes.technical_accuracy: Verify framework details against ALMA implementation in codebase
review_notes.cultural_sensitivity: Have First Nations partners review data sovereignty section
review_notes.stakeholder_review: May want funder/policy audience to review to ensure usefulness
review_notes.statistics: Any statistics used should be sourced from AIHW or peer-reviewed research
